His restless and turbulent disposi— tion induced him to plan methods whereby he might circumvent or vanqnish Oaherkaikin, and others of his rivals, not from the hope of emolument, but from the desire of overthrowing the celebrity they had obtained. This caused him to be always sowing dissensions, and hunt- ing out occasions of quarrels, which proved the source of numerous disturbances in the new town, and prevented it from ever enjoying a respite from its enemies. Though at other times mild and courteOUS, when scheming expe- ditions against his adversary‚ he deprived his dearest friends of his conversation.
